channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Three ways to recognize hidden labour in research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01749-3

From designing studies and translating science to technical services, the work of support staff is highly diverse — and it needs merit systems to match.
item.dc:title: Three ways to recognize hidden labour in research
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: Cyberattacks are hitting research institutions — with devastating effects
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01711-3

Hackers are targeting universities and research institutes with ransomware, leaving staff and students without the ability to work.
item.dc:title: Cyberattacks are hitting research institutions — with devastating effects
item.dc:creator: Diana Kwon

item.title: A Multimodal Generative AI Copilot for Human Pathology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07618-3

A Multimodal Generative AI Copilot for Human Pathology
item.dc:title: A Multimodal Generative AI Copilot for Human Pathology

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07668-7

Oligomerization-mediated autoinhibition and cofactor binding of a plant NLR

item.content:encoded:

Interactions between immune cell types facilitate the evolution of immune traits

item.content:encoded:

Maize smart-canopy architecture enhances yield at high densities
item.dc:title: Maize smart-canopy architecture enhances yield at high densities

item.title: A glass that builds and heals itself
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01750-w

The accidental discovery could be used to make lenses, or even as a glue.
item.dc:title: A glass that builds and heals itself
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: Hybrid working works: huge study reveals no drop in productivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01763-5

Working from home two days a week improved staff retention and satisfaction — plus a detailed look at the effects of spaceflight on the human body.
item.dc:title: Hybrid working works: huge study reveals no drop in productivity
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Fabrication of red-emitting perovskite LEDs by stabilizing their octahedral structure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07531-9

Red-emitting perovskite LEDs were fabricated by stabilizing their octahedral structure with a ligand to yield devices with enhanced efficiency, spectral stability and lifetime.
item.dc:title: Fabrication of red-emitting perovskite LEDs by stabilizing their octahedral structure
item.dc:creator: Lingmei Kong

item.title: Endoplasmic reticulum–plasma membrane contact gradients direct cell migration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07527-5

The density and size of contact gradients between the endoplasmic reticulum and the plasma membrane control the speed and direction of cell migration by restricting receptor signalling to the front.
item.dc:title: Endoplasmic reticulum–plasma membrane contact gradients direct cell migration
item.dc:creator: Bo Gong
Jake D. Johnston
Alexander Thiemicke
Alex de Marco
Tobias Meyer

item.title: Ancient Plasmodium genomes shed light on the history of human malaria
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07546-2

Genomic analysis of Plasmodium DNA from 36 ancient individuals provides insight into the global distribution and spread of malaria-causing species during around 5,500 years of human history.
item.dc:title: Ancient Plasmodium genomes shed light on the history of human malaria

item.title: CTLA-4-expressing ILC3s restrain interleukin-23-mediated inflammation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07537-3

Subsets of ILC3s upregulate the immunoregulatory checkpoint molecule CTLA-4 after stimulation in a microbiota-dependent manner, and advances to support CTLA-4+ ILC3s may represent a treatment opportunity in IL-23-driven chronic inflammation.
item.dc:title: CTLA-4-expressing ILC3s restrain interleukin-23-mediated inflammation
item.dc:creator: Anees Ahmed

item.title: The respiratory system influences flight mechanics in soaring birds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07485-y

An investigation of the subpectoral diverticulum—an inflatable air sac structure between the major flight muscles—in 68 avian species reveals that the respiratory system has a role in the mechanics of flight in soaring birds.
item.dc:title: The respiratory system influences flight mechanics in soaring birds
item.dc:creator: Emma R. Schachner
Andrew J. Moore
Aracely Martinez
Raul E. Diaz Jr
M. Scott Echols
Jessie Atterholt
Roger W. P. Kissane
Brandon P. Hedrick
Karl T. Bates

item.title: DNA mismatch and damage patterns revealed by single-molecule sequencing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07532-8

A DNA sequencing method with single-molecule fidelity detects mismatches and damage present in only one of the two DNA strands with patterns that are both similar and distinct compared to known mutation patterns.
item.dc:title: DNA mismatch and damage patterns revealed by single-molecule sequencing
item.dc:creator: Mei Hong Liu
Benjamin M. Costa

item.title: Onset of coupled atmosphere–ocean oxygenation 2.3 billion years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07551-5

The Great Oxidation Event represents a tipping point in Earth’s O2 mass balance—when more O2 was being produced than destroyed—that forever changed the habitability of worldwide oceans.
item.dc:title: Onset of coupled atmosphere–ocean oxygenation 2.3 billion years ago
item.dc:creator: Chadlin M. Ostrander
Andy W. Heard
Yunchao Shu
Andrey Bekker
Simon W. Poulton
Kasper P. Olesen
Sune G. Nielsen

item.title: Possible shift in controls of the tropical Pacific surface warming pattern
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07452-7

Focusing on the role of external forcing, an investigation of the causes of observed changes in the tropical Pacific surface warming pattern over recent decades discusses a possible shift in the drivers of this pattern.
item.dc:title: Possible shift in controls of the tropical Pacific surface warming pattern
item.dc:creator: Masahiro Watanabe
Sarah M. Kang
Matthew Collins
Yen-Ting Hwang
Shayne McGregor
Malte F. Stuecker

item.title: Ancient genomes reveal insights into ritual life at Chichén Itzá
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07509-7

We present genome-wide data from 64 subadults interred in Chichén Itzá around ad 500–900 that gives insight into burial rituals, and shows that their genomic legacy is still present and has adapted to immune challenges post-1492.
item.dc:title: Ancient genomes reveal insights into ritual life at Chichén Itzá
item.dc:creator: Rodrigo Barquera
Oana Del Castillo-Chávez
Kathrin Nägele

item.title: Strand-resolved mutagenicity of DNA damage and repair
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07490-1

How strand-asymmetric processes such as replication and transcription interact with DNA damage to drive mechanisms of repair and mutagenesis is explored.
item.dc:title: Strand-resolved mutagenicity of DNA damage and repair
item.dc:creator: Craig J. Anderson
Lana Talmane

item.title: Global variability in atmospheric new particle formation mechanisms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07547-1

Molecular-level experiments are described to develop a detailed assessment of 11 new particle formation mechanisms in a global climate model and, in comparison with simulations and observations, the dominant mechanisms worldwide are mapped.
item.dc:title: Global variability in atmospheric new particle formation mechanisms
item.dc:creator: Bin Zhao
Neil M. Donahue

item.title: A self-healing multispectral transparent adhesive peptide glass
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07408-x

A tyrosine tripeptide was discovered to unexpectedly form a supramolecular amorphous glassy material by constructing a non-specific hydrogen bonding network with structural water molecules.
item.dc:title: A self-healing multispectral transparent adhesive peptide glass
item.dc:creator: Gal Finkelstein-Zuta
Zohar A. Arnon
Thangavel Vijayakanth

item.title: Experiment-free exoskeleton assistance via learning in simulation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07382-4

A learning-in-simulation framework for wearable robots uses dynamics-aware musculoskeletal and exoskeleton models and data-driven reinforcement learning to bridge the gap between simulation and reality without human experiments to assist versatile activities.
item.dc:title: Experiment-free exoskeleton assistance via learning in simulation
item.dc:creator: Shuzhen Luo
Menghan Jiang
Sainan Zhang
Junxi Zhu
Shuangyue Yu
Israel Dominguez Silva

Hao Su

item.title: Optical manipulation of the charge-density-wave state in RbV<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07519-5

The charge-density-wave state in RbV3Sb5 can be optically manipulated by applying linearly polarized light along high-symmetry directions, which demonstrates the potential of light as a control knob to manipulate complex quantum phenomena in correlated materials.
item.dc:title: Optical manipulation of the charge-density-wave state in RbV<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5</sub>
item.dc:creator: Yuqing Xing
Seokjin Bae
Ethan Ritz
Fan Yang
Turan Birol
Andrea N. Capa Salinas
Brenden R. Ortiz
Stephen D. Wilson
Ziqiang Wang
Rafael M. Fernandes
Vidya Madhavan

item.title: Sleep loss diminishes hippocampal reactivation and replay
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07538-2

A study of neuronal activity in rats finds that sleep loss adversely affects hippocampal function and memory by dissociating hippocampal sharp-wave ripples from memory replay and reactivation events.
item.dc:title: Sleep loss diminishes hippocampal reactivation and replay
item.dc:creator: Bapun Giri
Nathaniel Kinsky
Utku Kaya
Kourosh Maboudi
Ted Abel
Kamran Diba

item.title: Hybrid working from home improves retention without damaging performance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07500-2

A trial investigating the effects of a hybrid working schedule in a Chinese technology firm in 2021–2022 shows that working from home two days a week improved job satisfaction, reduced quitting and did not affect performance.
item.dc:title: Hybrid working from home improves retention without damaging performance
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bloom
Ruobing Han
James Liang

item.title: Genetic drivers and cellular selection of female mosaic X chromosome loss
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07533-7

A large-scale meta-analysis across eight biobank datasets identifies common genetic variants associated with mosaic loss of the X chromosome in female participants.
item.dc:title: Genetic drivers and cellular selection of female mosaic X chromosome loss
item.dc:creator: Aoxing Liu
Giulio Genovese

item.title: A two-site Kitaev chain in a two-dimensional electron gas
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07434-9

We have implemented a two-site Kitaev chain in a two-dimensional electron gas by coupling quantum dots through Andreev bound states in a superconductor–semiconductor hybrid region.
item.dc:title: A two-site Kitaev chain in a two-dimensional electron gas
item.dc:creator: Sebastiaan L. D. ten Haaf
Qingzhen Wang
A. Mert Bozkurt
Chun-Xiao Liu

Tom Dvir
Michael Wimmer
Srijit Goswami

item.title: Obesity induces PD-1 on macrophages to suppress anti-tumour immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07529-3

A study demonstrates that metabolic signalling and inflammatory cues associated with obesity selectively induce expression of PD-1 on tumour-associated macrophages to suppress anti-tumour immunity.
item.dc:title: Obesity induces PD-1 on macrophages to suppress anti-tumour immunity
item.dc:creator: Jackie E. Bader
Melissa M. Wolf

Alyssa H. Hasty
Jeffrey C. Rathmell

item.title: Mental navigation in the primate entorhinal cortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07557-z

Measurements of activity in the entorhinal cortex of monkeys indicate that the recruitment of a cognitive map is a key part of mental navigation, and that cognitive maps can support behavior in the absence of external sensory input.
item.dc:title: Mental navigation in the primate entorhinal cortex
item.dc:creator: Sujaya Neupane
Ila Fiete
Mehrdad Jazayeri

item.title: Inner core backtracking by seismic waveform change reversals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07536-4

Matching seismic waveforms show that the inner core of Earth gradually super-rotated from 2003 to 2008, and then more slowly sub-rotated from 2008 to 2023 back through the same path.
item.dc:title: Inner core backtracking by seismic waveform change reversals
item.dc:creator: Wei Wang
John E. Vidale
Guanning Pang
Keith D. Koper
Ruoyan Wang

item.title: Tunable entangled photon-pair generation in a liquid crystal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07543-5

Electric-field tunable generation of entangled photon pairs is achieved by spontaneous parametric down-conversion in a ferroelectric nematic liquid crystal, with an efficiency comparable to that of the best nonlinear crystals.
item.dc:title: Tunable entangled photon-pair generation in a liquid crystal
item.dc:creator: Vitaliy Sultanov
Aljaž Kavčič
Emmanouil Kokkinakis
Nerea Sebastián
Maria V. Chekhova
Matjaž Humar

item.title: Self-healing glass from a simple peptide — just add water
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01505-7

A simple peptide has been found to make disordered interactions with water, forming a self-healing glass that can also be used as an adhesive coating. The findings point the way to sustainable alternatives to conventional glass.
item.dc:title: Self-healing glass from a simple peptide — just add water
item.dc:creator: Silvia Marchesan

item.title: The climate crisis is solvable, but human rights must trump profits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01762-6

Huge planetary problems were fixed in the past, yielding lessons for the current climate crisis — yet this time a solution is justice.
item.dc:title: The climate crisis is solvable, but human rights must trump profits
item.dc:creator: Friederike Otto

item.title: Air sacs reduce energy costs for soaring birds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01508-4

Certain air sacs have evolved in multiple lineages of soaring birds, and it emerges that these probably function to reduce the force required from the major flight muscles as they hold the wings in place during gliding and soaring.
item.dc:title: Air sacs reduce energy costs for soaring birds
item.dc:creator: Bret W. Tobalske

item.title: Ribosomes unexpectedly moonlight as activators of angiogenin enzyme
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01510-w

The enzyme angiogenin functions in stress responses and aids the formation of blood vessels. It emerges that the ribosome takes a break from its usual role of making proteins to activate angiogenin and position it to cleave transfer RNA.
item.dc:title: Ribosomes unexpectedly moonlight as activators of angiogenin enzyme
item.dc:creator: Pavel Ivanov

item.title: Hybrid working has benefits over fully in-person working — the evidence mounts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01713-1

Some employers are backing away from hybrid working, but research suggests that they need not be concerned.
item.dc:title: Hybrid working has benefits over fully in-person working — the evidence mounts

item.title: To save the high seas, plan for climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01720-2

Species are already on the move as waters warm. Conservation plans need to take this into account.
item.dc:title: To save the high seas, plan for climate change
item.dc:creator: Lee Hannah
Amy Irvine
Isaac Brito-Morales
Susanna Fuller
Tammy Davies
Derek Tittensor
Grace Reville
Nancy Shackell
Janos Hennicke
Ryan Stanley

item.title: Sleep deprivation disrupts memory: here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01732-y

Study in rats shows that a key brain signal linked to memory formation deteriorates after broken sleep.
item.dc:title: Sleep deprivation disrupts memory: here’s why
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Robotic exoskeleton adapts to its wearer through simulated training
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01506-6

A strategy for training a robotic exoskeleton through simulation takes the user out of the equation — saving users of wearable devices time and energy, and smoothing the transition between different types of movement.
item.dc:title: Robotic exoskeleton adapts to its wearer through simulated training
item.dc:creator: Alexandra S. Voloshina

item.title: Hope, despair and CRISPR — the race to save one woman’s life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01716-y

Researchers in India fought to develop what could have been the first therapy to use gene-editing to halt a rare neurodegenerative disease. The efforts hold lessons for the messy state of modern drug development.
item.dc:title: Hope, despair and CRISPR — the race to save one woman’s life
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Brain senses immune reactions in the body through the vagus nerve
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01636-x

A newly characterized neural circuit enables the brain to sense and monitor inflammatory responses in the body, and in turn shape the course of the immune reaction. Artificial activation of components of this body–brain circuit in mouse models of inflammation and immune disorders prevented uncontrolled and dysregulated inflammatory reactions.
item.dc:title: Brain senses immune reactions in the body through the vagus nerve

item.title: Ancient DNA from Maya ruins tells story of ritual human sacrifices
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01759-1

Children sacrificed at Chichén Itzá have genetic links to people living near the ancient Maya city in Mexico, and hint at the effects of colonial-era epidemics.
item.dc:title: Ancient DNA from Maya ruins tells story of ritual human sacrifices
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Plastic-eating fungus caused doomsday<sup>[2][3]</sup>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01723-z

A collaborative effort.
item.dc:title: Plastic-eating fungus caused doomsday<sup>[2][3]</sup>
item.dc:creator: Emma Burnett

item.title: CRISPR cures and cancer vaccines: researchers can help to shepherd them to market
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01714-0

It’s not just people with ultra-rare disorders who could benefit from hyper-personalized therapies. Scientists and regulators must work together to ensure the benefits are spread.
item.dc:title: CRISPR cures and cancer vaccines: researchers can help to shepherd them to market

item.title: A virtual rodent predicts the structure of neural activity across behaviors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07633-4

A virtual rodent predicts the structure of neural activity across behaviors
item.dc:title: A virtual rodent predicts the structure of neural activity across behaviors

item.title: Science profits most when people of faith feel equally welcomed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01745-7

Science profits most when people of faith feel equally welcomed
item.dc:title: Science profits most when people of faith feel equally welcomed
item.dc:creator: Denis R. Alexander
Robert S. White

item.title: Ancient graves reveal taxes’ sharp bite nearly 3,000 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01700-6

Buried items show that the poor got poorer as the Assyrian empire and its bureaucracy swelled.
item.dc:title: Ancient graves reveal taxes’ sharp bite nearly 3,000 years ago

item.title: Physics is more than a collection of laws — it is a living craft
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01590-8

The Cavendish Laboratory’s director, Brian Pippard, comments on the landscape of physics research in 1974, plus the benefits of applying thermodynamics to physiology, in the weekly dip in Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: Physics is more than a collection of laws — it is a living craft

item.title: Equality doesn’t equal sustainability — even high-welfare states must do more
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01746-6

Equality doesn’t equal sustainability — even high-welfare states must do more
item.dc:title: Equality doesn’t equal sustainability — even high-welfare states must do more
item.dc:creator: David Pérez-Neira
Sherman Farhad
Luis Buendía

item.title: CRISPR improves a crop that feeds billions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01701-5

The gene-editing system, normally used to disrupt a gene, is applied to improve the function of a gene in rice.
item.dc:title: CRISPR improves a crop that feeds billions

item.title: Science and religion have profound differences — they should be kept apart
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01744-8

Science and religion have profound differences — they should be kept apart
item.dc:title: Science and religion have profound differences — they should be kept apart
item.dc:creator: Rodrigo Hirata Willemart
Antonio Carlos Marques

item.title: Embryo models need consistent ethical oversight
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01728-8

Embryo models need consistent ethical oversight
item.dc:title: Embryo models need consistent ethical oversight
item.dc:creator: Magdalena Zernicka-Goetz
Insoo Hyun

item.title: A win for global action: harm from some ozone-eroding gases starts to fall
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01733-x

Emissions reductions achieved under the landmark Montreal Protocol mean that the ozone hole could close sooner than expected.
item.dc:title: A win for global action: harm from some ozone-eroding gases starts to fall

item.title: How personalized cancer vaccines could keep tumours from coming back
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01717-x

The same mRNA technology that quickly brought the world a vaccine for COVID-19 is now showing promise as a bespoke therapy for cancer.
item.dc:title: How personalized cancer vaccines could keep tumours from coming back
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Open access is working — but researchers in lower-income countries enjoy fewer benefits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01748-4

Deep-seated aspects of local research systems need to be uprooted to ensure that researchers in low-income countries can harness the advantages of open access.
item.dc:title: Open access is working — but researchers in lower-income countries enjoy fewer benefits
item.dc:creator: Holly Else

item.title: Space weather can affect our daily lives — we need a better warning system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01715-z

Categorizing geomagnetic storms on a scale of one to five leaves no room for once-a-century superstorms.
item.dc:title: Space weather can affect our daily lives — we need a better warning system
item.dc:creator: Sean Elvidge

item.title: How restorative justice could help to heal science communities torn apart by harassment misconduct
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01739-5

Could a programme used by police to tackle repeat offending be used in academia? Some institutions are keen to find out.
item.dc:title: How restorative justice could help to heal science communities torn apart by harassment misconduct
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wild

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: The year machines will run out of data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01760-8

Large language models could exhaust the supply of publicly available, human-crafted writing in the next two to eight years. Plus, AI model finds huge cache of potential antibiotics hidden in genomes and Microsoft’s algorithm predicts global air pollution in less than a minute.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: The year machines will run out of data
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Elite researchers in China say they had ‘no choice’ but to commit misconduct
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01697-y

Anonymous interviewees say they engaged in unethical behaviour to protect their jobs — although others say study presents an overly negative view.
item.dc:title: Elite researchers in China say they had ‘no choice’ but to commit misconduct
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: How a few days in space can disrupt a person’s biology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01705-1

Trove of health data from space tourists and astronauts reveals the effects of microgravity, radiation and more.
item.dc:title: How a few days in space can disrupt a person’s biology
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Author Correction: Loss of CDK4/6 activity in S/G2 phase leads to cell cycle reversal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07666-9

Author Correction: Loss of CDK4/6 activity in S/G2 phase leads to cell cycle reversal
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Loss of CDK4/6 activity in S/G2 phase leads to cell cycle reversal
item.dc:creator: James A. Cornwell
Adrijana Crncec
Marwa M. Afifi
Kristina Tang
Ruhul Amin
Steven D. Cappell

item.title: I raise delicate butterflies on the mean streets of New York
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01722-0

Robyn Elman works to protect and conserve monarch butterflies before their dangerous migration down the US East Coast to Mexico.
item.dc:title: I raise delicate butterflies on the mean streets of New York
item.dc:creator: Jack Leeming

item.title: Do elephants have names for each other?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00797-z

Machine learning and careful observation suggest that some of the animals’ calls are specific to individuals, similar to a person’s name.
item.dc:title: Do elephants have names for each other?
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Most nearby young star clusters formed in three massive complexes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07496-9

Analysis of data from Gaia Data Release 3 and other large spectroscopic surveys shows that nearly 60% of high-quality young clusters within 1 kpc of the Sun originated from just three distinct star-forming complexes.
item.dc:title: Most nearby young star clusters formed in three massive complexes
item.dc:creator: Cameren Swiggum
João Alves
Robert Benjamin
Sebastian Ratzenböck
Núria Miret-Roig
Josefa Großschedl
Stefan Meingast
Alyssa Goodman
Ralf Konietzka
Catherine Zucker
Emily L. Hunt
Sabine Reffert

item.title: What the science of elections can reveal in this super-election year
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01712-2

As billions of people go to the polls in 2024, political scientists have a lot of data to sift through.
item.dc:title: What the science of elections can reveal in this super-election year
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Plackett

item.title: Daily briefing: Good news for Moderna’s two-in-one COVID and flu vaccine
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01752-8

A combined jab against COVID-19 and influenza has produced positive results in a large clinical trial. Plus, magic tricks reveal how animals think and what to do if you’re denied tenure.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Good news for Moderna’s two-in-one COVID and flu vaccine
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Counting the cost of fashion’s carbon footprint
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01743-9

As a child Sonja Salmon loved chemistry and sewing. Now her research explores ways of reducing the textile industry’s environmental impact.
item.dc:title: Counting the cost of fashion’s carbon footprint
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: How we packed off the giant pandas from the Smithsonian’s National Zoo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01727-9

As the zoo prepares to welcome two giant pandas from China, its director Brandie Smith discusses the departure of their predecessors, Tian Tian, Mei Xiang and a three-year-old cub.
item.dc:title: How we packed off the giant pandas from the Smithsonian’s National Zoo
item.dc:creator: Anne Gulland

item.title: Far-right gains in European elections: what they mean for climate goals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01742-w

A political shift to the right in Europe could make it harder to bring in more ambitious green policies, but key net-zero commitments should remain.
item.dc:title: Far-right gains in European elections: what they mean for climate goals
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: How to track the economic impact of public investments in AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01721-1

National statistics systems should recognize the researchers whose ideas drive artificial-intelligence applications, not just machines and factory outputs.
item.dc:title: How to track the economic impact of public investments in AI
item.dc:creator: Julia Lane
Jason Owen-Smith
Bruce A. Weinberg

item.title: Alzheimer’s drug with modest benefits wins backing of FDA advisers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01726-w

Donanemab slows progression of symptoms, but questions linger about the durability of its effect.
item.dc:title: Alzheimer’s drug with modest benefits wins backing of FDA advisers
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Two decades of deep ice cores from Antarctica
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01507-5

In June 2004, the results of an ambitious Antarctic ice-drilling project brought insight into hundreds of thousands of years of climatic changes. The extraordinary sample still has much to offer climate research — even as its successor is being drilled.
item.dc:title: Two decades of deep ice cores from Antarctica
item.dc:creator: Kenji Kawamura
Ikumi Oyabu
